ACC 8023.course_description: (Prerequisites: ACC 3013 and Graduate Standing). Three hours lecture. Course presents business concepts and significance of the professional duties of accountants and responsibilities within the larger context of the business environment. Emphasis is placed on developing an advanced understanding of fundamental and current issues facing the managerial accountant

ACC 8013.course_description: (Prerequisites: Graduate Standing; ACC 3033). Three hours lecture. Examination of the theoretical concepts, definitions, and models espoused in the accounting literature and relevant to analyzing various contemporary issues in financial accounting and reporting

ACC 8043.course_description: (Prerequisites: ACC 2013 and Graduate Standing). Three hours lecture. The course covers the nature of fraud, fraud examination, and the communication of the findings from a fraud examination. Emphasis will be placed on the use of advanced data analysis techniques and procedures to detect errors and frauds

ACC 8033.course_description: (Prerequisites: ACC 4033 and Graduate Standing). Three hours lecture. Students gain in-depth knowledge of professional auditing standards, financial statement auditing procedures, and audit reporting requirements. Students develop data analysis skills applicable to auditing. Students gain exposure to theoretical arguments surrounding professional rules of conduct and audit quality indicators

ACC 4033.course_description: (Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in ACC 3003 and ACC 3023). Three hours lecture. Fundamentals of auditing, including evaluating controls, assessing risk, designing audit programs, statistical sampling, professional ethics, and collecting evidence for financial, internal, operational, and compliance audits

FIN 3123.course_description: (Prerequisites: EC 2123, ACC 2013, and BQA 2113 ). Three hours lecture. Study of objectives, tools, methods, and problems of financial management; financial analysis, planning, control, sources/uses of funds, capital budgeting decisions and working capital

ACC 6063.course_description: (Prerequisites: Undergraduate-Grade of C or better in ACC 4013; Graduate-ACC 4013 and Graduate Standing). Three hours lecture. Students will be exposed to an overview of Corporate taxation, Partnership taxation, and Estate and Gift taxation

ACC 8113.course_name: Advanced Individual Taxation and Wealth Management:
ACC 8113.course_description: (Prerequisites: ACC 4013 and Graduate Standing). Three hours lecture. This course is designed to provide an enhanced understanding of the U.S. Federal Income Tax System. Emphasis will be placed on complex tax issues encountered by individual taxpayers

EC 2113.course_description: Three hours lecture. Introduction to macroeconomics: free enterprise principles, policies, institutions; national income, employment, output, inflation, money, credit, business cycles, and government finances

BL 2413.course_description: Three hours lecture. Environmental study of legal influences, concepts, institutions, emphasizing social forces shaping business law. Introduces business students to interrelationships of law and society, jurisprudence and business

ACC 8183.course_description: (Prerequisites: ACC 3033 and Graduate Standing). Three hours lecture. A study of the international dimension of accounting as it relates to multinational corporations and the international environment. Some specific topics include: international financial reporting; financial reporting outside the USA; foreign exchange; accounting harmonization; international financial disclosure issues

ACC 2023.course_description: (Prerequisite: ACC 2013; ACC majors must have a grade of B or better in ACC 2013). Three hours lecture. Managerial accounting fundamentals including interpretation and use of management reports, cost behavior, cost accumulation, budgeting, financial statement analysis, responsibility organizations. Honors section available

ACC 2013.course_description: Three hours lecture. Financial accounting fundamentals including accounting cycle, accounting systems, cash flow, assets, liabilities, equity, and forms of business organizations.Honors section available

ACC 8123.course_description: (Prerequisites: ACC 4013 and Graduate Standing). Three hours lecture. The course exposes students to tax topics that are not covered in the other MTX courses. Specialized topics include individual taxation, entity taxation, estate and gift taxation, state tax issues, and ethics

ACC 8063.course_name: Research in Tax Practice and Procedures:
ACC 8063.course_description: (Prerequisites: ACC 4013 and Graduate Standing). Three hours lecture. Students will gain an in-depth knowledge of the sources of tax authority. Emphasis will be placed on the using tax law to prepare tax strategy and identify planning opportunities

ACC 3023.course_description: (Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in ACC 2013 and ACC 2023). Three hours lecture. Students will gain in-depth knowledge of financial accounting and reporting related to the development of accounting standards, financial statements, income measurement, cash, receivables, inventory, property, plant, and equipment, intangibles, and other financial topics

ACC 8093.course_name: Taxation of Partnerships, S Corporations, Trusts, and Estates:
ACC 8093.course_description: (Prerequisites: ACC 4013 and Graduate Standing). Three hours lecture. The course introduces students to federal taxation of partnerships and S Corporations.  The course uses both cases and problems to identify and provide solutions to tax problems and issues

ACC 8073.course_description: (Prerequisites: ACC 4013 and Graduate Standing). Three hours lecture. Students will gain an in-depth knowledge of corporate taxation

ACC 2203.course_description: Fundamentals of financial, managerial, and cost accounting for interpreting accounting reports. Primarily for engineering and pre-MBA students. (Not open to undergrad accounting or business majors)

ACC 8053.course_description: (Prerequisites: ACC 3033 and Graduate Standing). Three hours lecture. This is an integrative course examining recent trends and developments in public accounting. It includes various problems and cases in accounting and related business issues, ethics, and other topics

EC 2123.course_description: Three hours lecture. Introduction to microeconomics: emphasizes American industrial structure, demand and supply, pricing and output, income distribution, factor pricing, international trade

ACC 3013.course_description: (Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in ACC 2013 and ACC 2023). Three hours lecture. The course focuses on using accounting information to make management decisions; including measurement and behavior of product costs, cost-volume-profit analysis, budgeting issues and cost reports

ACC 3033.course_description: (Prerequisite: Grade of C or better in ACC 3023).Three hours lecture. Financial accounting and reporting related to liabilities, leases, pensions, income taxes, stockholder's equity, accounting changes, errors, cash flows, and earnings per share

ACC 3003.course_description: (Prerequisite: Grade of B or better in ACC 2013 and ACC 2023). Three hours lecture. The course will help the conceptualization (design), development, implementation, documentation, and use of accounting information systems. Also, the course will leverage the power of dynamic spreadsheets to facilitate dynamic financial analysis

ACC 4013.course_description: (Prerequisites: Grade of B or better in ACC 2013). Three hours lecture. This course provides an introduction to the U.S. Federal Income Tax System by introducing the fundamental structure of the Federal Income Tax System and examining the tax impact on personal and business decisions

EM 4143.course_description: (Prerequisite:Consent of instructor ) Three hours lecture. Introduction to optimality criteria and optimization techniques for solving constrained or unconstrained optimization problems. Sensitivity analysis and approximation. Computer application in optimization. Introduction to MDO. (Same as ASE 4553/6553 and IE 4743/6743 )

ASE 3813.course_description: (Prerequisities:Grade of C or better in EM 2433, MA 3253 and MA 3113).Three hours lecture. Two-body orbital mechanics;geometry of spatial orbits; fundamental orbits determination;orbital maneuvers; introduction to rendezvous and interplanetary trajectories

IE 4743.course_description: (Prerequisite: Consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. Introduction to optimality criteria and optimization techniques for solving constrained or unconstrained optimization problems. Sensitivity analysis and approximation. Computer application in optimization. Introduction to MDO. ( Same as ASE 4553/6553 and EM 4143/6143 )

ECE 4913.course_description: (Prerequisite: Grade of C or better in ECE 3443). Three hours lecture. Laplace transforms; transient and frequency response of feedback systems; transfer functions; Nyquist criterion, root locus; compensation of feedback systems; logarithmic analysis and design

ASE 4343.course_description: (Prerequisites:ASE 3333 & Grade of C or better in EM 3313). Three hours lecture. Equations of motion for multidimensional flow; oblique shock waves; Prandtl Meyer flow; internal flow; method of characteristics; linearized flows; compressible wing theory; compressible boundary layers

EM 3413.course_description: (Prerequisites:Grade of C or better in EM 2433,  MA 3253 and MA 3113).Three hours lecture. Fundamentals of free vibration, energy methods; forced and damped vibration, single degree of freedom; two degrees of freedom

ASE 2113.course_name: Introduction to Aircraft and Spacecraft Performance:
ASE 2113.course_description: (Prerequisite: ASE 1013 and CSE 1233 and grade of C or better in MA 1723 and PH 2213). Three hours lecture. Introduction to general aerodynamics, propulsive and structural considerations of flight mechanics, quasi-steady flight; accelerated and maneuvering flight; launch vehicle performance

ASE 3333.course_description: (Prerequisites:Grade of C or better in MA 2733 and PH 2213). Three hours lecture. Energy; First and Second Laws of Thermodynamics; Entropy; Properties of Ideal Gases, Gas Power Cycles;  Introduction to Heat Transfer

CHE 3113.course_description: (Prerequisites:  C or better in CH 1223 and PH 2213.  Co-requisites:  CHE 2114 and MA 2733).  Three hours lecture.  Thermodynamic properties, energy relationships, applications of the first and second law of thermodynamics, flow processes, power cycles, refrigeration and liquefaction

ASE 3313.course_description: (Prerequisite:Grade of C or better in  EM 3313). Three hours lectures. Potential theory of bodies; airfoil theory and applications; finite wing theory and applications; introduction to Navier-Stokes equations; laminar boundary layers; turbulent boundary layers

ASE 8343.course_description: (Prerequisite: Consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. Incompressible Navier-Stokes equations; properties and exact solutions; laminar boundary layer equations; two- and three-dimensional solutions; time-dependent solutions; approximate solutions; boundary layer control

ASE 8413.course_description: (Prerequisite: Consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. Review of relevant numerical analysis; one dimensional methods; compressible inviscid methods, Euler Equation methods, inviscid-viscous interaction methods; current literature

ASE 4123.course_description: (Prerequisite: ASE 3123 or ASE 3823). Three hours lecture. Methods of dynamic analysis; stability of steady flight; response to actuation of the controls (open loop); closed-loop control ;human crew/vehicle interactions

ECE 8943.course_description: (Prerequisite:ASE 4123 or ECE 4913/6913 or equivalent). Three hours lecture. State variable description of systems; maximum principle of Pontryagin, dynamic programming, optimization of linear systems with quadratic performance measures; time optimal and fuel optimal systems. (Same as ASE 8863)

ME 3513.course_description: (Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CH 1213, CH 1211, MA 2733, and PH 2213). Three hours lecture. Definitions; properties of a pure substance; work and heat; First and Second Laws; entropy; ideal gases

ASE 4813.course_description: (Prerequisite: ASE 3813). Three hours lecture. Orbital mechanics; perturbations and numerical integration. Global positioning system, launch performance and optimization

ASE 8313.course_description: (Prerequisite: ASE 4343 or equivalent). Three hours lecture. Derivation of complete equations for compressible fluid flow; unsteady one-dimensional flows; method of characteristics; flow about two-dimensional and axis-symmetric shapes; integral methods

MKT 8153.course_description: Three hours lecture.  Market strategic analysis, research and planning necessary to effectively match marketing strategies with changing macro, micro and organizational environments

AEC 6113.course_description: (Prerequisites: EC 3123 or consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. Examination and study of the organization, management, and operation of agricultural business with special reference to the application of managerial principles for effective decision-making

BQA 8443.course_description: (Prerequisites: Proficiency with spreadsheet software).Three hours lecture. Review of descriptive statistics, parametric inference procedures, analysis of variance, regression, nonparametric methods; business problem formulation for computer analysis using statistical packages

BQA 2113.course_description: (Prerequisite: MA 1613 or MA 1713 and BIS 1012 or equivalent). Three hours lecture. Methods of describing numerical data; probability in business decisions; random variables; sampling distributions; introduction to estimation and hypothesis testing; computer statistical packages applied

EC 4043.course_description: (Prerequisite: Senior or  Graduate standing). Three hours lecture. Introduction to macro and microeconomics, national income accounts, monetary system, macroeconomic policy, international trade, supply and demand, distribution of income, markets, pricing,and output. (Not open to BACC or BBA Business majors )

FIN 8113.course_description: (Prerequisite: Graduate Standing and Grade B or better in FIN 3123 or equivalent).  Three hours lecture.  An examination of the interaction between financial accounting, cash flow estimation, capital budgeting, risk and return, capital structure, and working capital management

MGT 8063.course_description: (Prerequisite: Graduate standing). Three hours lecture. Survey of management principles and techniques including: objective, policies, functions, leadership, organization, and production control procedures and systems as applied to all fields of business

AEC 6530.course_description: (Prerequisite: Consent of instructor). Individual work experience with approved agribusiness companies for environmental economics and management students or agribusiness students. (May be repeated for up to a total of 6 hours of credit)

EC 8103.course_description: (Prerequisites:  Graduate Standing and FIN 3123 or equivalent).  Three hours lecture.  Primarily for masters level candidates.  Exposition of the fundamental theoretical and analytical tools of  economics used by business managers engaged in decision making

AEC 6223.course_name: Applied Quantitative Analysis in Agricultural Economics:
AEC 6223.course_description: (Prerequisite: AEC 3113; and BQA 2113 or ST 2113 or ST 3123; or consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. Emphasizes the intuitive understanding and practical application of basic quantitative, statistical, econometric, and optimization techniques as they relate to problem solving in agricultural economics

ACC 8213.course_name: Financial Statement and Management Accounting Report Analysis for Decision Making:
ACC 8213.course_description: (Prerequisites:  ACC 2203 or equivalent).  Three hours lecture.  Analysis of financial statements and internal accounting reports to help management make decisions

BQA 3123.course_description: (Prerequisite: BQA 2113 or equivalent). Three hours lecture. Reviewing estimation and hypothesis testing; correlation and regression; chi-square tests; analysis of variance; non-parametric concepts; index numbers; time series analysis; computer statistical packages applied

EC 3123.course_description: (Prerequisites: EC 2113 and EC 2123). Theory and application of microeconomics; demand, supply, optimal consumer choice, production, cost, profit-maximizing pricing and output decisions, employment of resources, externalities, efficiency and welfare

PSS 4543.course_description: (Prerequisite:  PSS/ABE 2543 and Junior Standing).  Two hours lecture.  Two hours lab.  Site-specific management techniques are examined.  Continuous decision-making processes of farm production are integrated using a whole-system, geospatial approach (same as ABE 4543/6543)

AEC 3413.course_description: (Prerequisites: AEC 2713 or EC 2123). Three hours lecture. Describes the principles, functions, agencies, and methods of farm and food product and input marketing

PSS 2543.course_description: (Prerequisite:  Sophomore standing and MA 1313).  Two hours lecture.  Two hours lab.  This introductory course highlights site-specific crop management techniques.  Topics include:  Best Management Practices, economic and physical farm production models, and measurement of variability (same as ABE 2543)

PSS 3301.course_description: (Prerequisite: Prior credit for/or current enrollment in PSS 3303, Co-requisite for Plant and Soil Sciences majors: PSS 3303). Two hours laboratory. General treatment of selected phases of the subject matter

EM 2433.course_description: (Prerequisites:Grade of C or better in  EM 2413 and MA 2733). Three hours lecture. Kinematics of particles and rigid bodies, kinetics of particles and rigid bodies using force-mass-acceleration, energy, momentum methods

ABE 8911.course_name: Agricultural and Biological Engineering Seminar I:
ABE 8911.course_description: One hour lecture. Discussion of research needs, review of literature, and development of research work plans

PSS 4823.course_description: (Prerequisite: PSS 3133 and Junior standing). Two hours lecture. Three hours laboratory. Classification and use of herbicides with emphasis on herbicides and emphasis on herbicides used in turfgrasses.  Credit may not be given for this course and PSS 4813/6813

AEC 4133.course_name: Analysis of Food Markets and Prices:
AEC 4133.course_description: (Prerequisites: AEC 3113 and EC 3123). Three hours lecture. Application of economic theory to agricultural prices and agricultural markets in price estimation, discovery, and determination. Emphasis on marketing management and pricing in agricultural firms

ME 3403.course_description: (Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CH 1223 and EM 2413, corequisite EM 3213 ). Three hours lecture. Behavior, testing and processing of engineering materials. Emphasis is placed on the inter- relation of design with processing and material selection

ABE 4000.course_name: Directed Individual Study in Agricultural and Biological Engineering:
ABE 4000.course_description: Hours and credits to be arranged

PSS 4333.course_description: (Prerequisite: PSS 3303). Two hours lecture . Three hours laboratory. Soil identification, topographic relationships and soil-water resources; their characteristics, quality, suitability, and management; conservation practices; using soil maps to determine land use

ABE 3413.course_description: (Prerequisite: PH 2223 or equivalent). Two hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Applied circuit analysis, electrodes and transducers, stress and strain, temperature measurements, human physiology, digital and programmable instrumentation

PSS 4313.course_description: (Prerequisite: PSS 3303 and junior standing). Three hours lecture. Fundamentals and concepts of soil fertility/nutrient management; fertilizer sources and crop response to nutrients; fertilizer production; and soil fertility evaluation and maintenance through organic and inorganic fertilization

EM 2413.course_description: (Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in MA 1723 and PH 2213).Three hours lecture or three hours recitation with online content delivery. Concepts of forces, moments and other vector quantities; analysis of force systems; conditions of equilibrium; friction; centroids and moments of inertia

PSS 4813.course_description: (Prerequisites: PSS 3133 and junior standing). Two hours lecture. Three hours laboratory. Classification and use of herbicides. A detailed look at herbicide application-field use and factors influencing herbicide activity. Credit may not be given for this course and PSS 4823/6823

ABE 2543.course_description: (Prerequisite:  Sophomore standing and MA 1313).  Two hours lecture.  Two hours lab.  This introductory course highlights site-specific crop management techniques.  Topics include:  Best Management Practices, economic and physical farm production models, and measurement of variability (same as PSS 2543)

EG 1143.course_description: Three hours lecture. Orthographic projection, instrumental drawing, point, line, plane identities, computer assisted design and drafting using personal computers

EPP 4214.course_description: (Prerequisites: EPP 3113 or 3124). Three hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Fundamentals and practical aspects of identification and control of selected diseases of crop plants grown in the southern U.S. Spring semester

EPP 4263.course_description: Two hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Discussion of pest management concepts, insect control methods, sampling, and pest management systems. Laboratory involves sampling, calibration, and other exercises related to pest management

PSS 3303.course_description: (Prerequisite: One semester (preferably two) of inorganic chemistry, CH 1043, Co-requisite for Plant and Soil Sciences majors: PSS 3301.) Three hours lecture. General treatment of all phases of the subject including lime and fertilizers

EPP 3124.course_description: Three hours lecture and two hours laboratory. Studies of the biology, ecology, damage, survey techniques, and management of forest insects and pathogens will be presented

EPP 4163.course_description: (Prerequisite: EPP 4113/6113 or consent of instructor). Two hours lecture. Three hours laboratory. Techniques and fundamentals of plant disease management. Disease dynamics related to management, avoidance, exclusion, eradication of pathogens; principles of plant protection, spraying techniques; biological control. Spring semester

CHE 3413.course_description: (Prerequisites:  C or better in CH 1223 and PH 2213).  Three hours lecture.  The physical, chemical, and mechanical properties of engineering materials.  The influence of these properties on the behavior of materials that have been placed in service

PSS 4373.course_description: (Prerequisites PSS 3303, PSS 3133). Three hours lecture. This class will utilize the basic tools of geographical information systems and geographical positioning systems technologies to analyze agronomic case studies

ABE 3513.course_name: The Global Positional System and Geographic Information Systems in Agriculture and Engineering:
ABE 3513.course_description: (Prerequisite: MA 1313 and MA 1323, or equivalent). Two hours lecture. Four hours laboratory. Basic theory and hands-on application of global positioning system (GPS) technology/hardware, and geographic information systems (GIS) software, for precise positioning in agriculture and engineering

EC 6423.course_description: (Perquisites: EC 2113,EC 2123 and EC 3123). Three hours lecture. Economics of the public sector. Analysis of government’s influence on distribution, allocation, and stabilization functions. Emphasis on public goods, externalities, social insurance, and taxation

ECE 6423.course_description: (Prerequisite: senior or graduate standing, or consent of instructor.) Three hours lecture. Electromagnetic interaction passive sensors, multispectral and hyperspectral optical sensors, active sensors, imaging radar, SAR, Lidar, digital image processing, natural resource applications. (Same as PSS 4483/6483 and ABE 4483/6483)

PSS 4113.course_description: Three hours lecture. Online course. Physiology of agricultural plants, including water relations, respiration, photosynthesis and growth and development

AEC 4113.course_description: (Prerequisites: EC 3123 or consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. Examination and study of the organization, management, and operation of agricultural business with special reference to the application of managerial principles for effective decision-making

BIO 4214.course_description: (Prerequisites: BIO 2113 and CH 1213). Three hours lecture. Three hours laboratory. Chemical and physical activities of the plant; absorption; transpiration; mineral nutrition; photosynthesis; translocation; growth processes

ABE 9000.course_name: Research in Agricultural and Biological Engineering:
ABE 9000.course_description: Hours and credits to be arranged

GR 4303.course_description: Two hours lecture and two hours laboratory. Spatial analysis and topological relationships of geographic data using Geographic Information Systems, with emphasis on GIS theory

GR 3303.course_description: (Prerequisite: GR 2313). Three hours lecture. Geographic Information Systems, Remote Sensing and Global Positioning Systems applied to earth systems and science. Includes field excursions for hands on experience with current technologies

ABE 6483.course_description: (Prerequisite: Senior or graduate standing, or consent or instructor). Three hours lecture. Electromagnetic interactions, passive sensors, multispectral and hyperspectral optical sensors, active sensors, imaging radar, SAR Lidar, digital image processing, natural resource applications. (Same as ECE 4423/6423 and PSS 4483/6483)

PSS 6483.course_description: (Prerequisite: Senior or graduate standing, or consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. Electromagnetic interactions, passive sensors, multispectral and hyperspectral optical sensors, active sensors, imaging radar, SAR, Lidar, digital image processing, natural resource applications (Same as ECE 4423/6423 and ABE 4483/6483)

ABE 6163.course_description: (Prerequisites: ABE 2173 or consent of instructor). Two hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Selection, sizing and operation machine systems using cost analysis and systems techniques. Emphasis on agricultural machines used in farming; tillage, planting, harvesting, and conveying agricultural materials

EPP 4234.course_description: (Prerequisite: EPP 2213 or 4154). Three hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Fall semester. Recognition, biology, distribution, damage, economic importance and methods of control of insect pests of agronomic and horticultural crops

EC 4423.course_description: (Perquisites: EC 2113,EC 2123 and EC 3123). Three hours lecture. Economics of the public sector. Analysis of government’s influence on distribution, allocation, and stabilization functions. Emphasis on public goods, externalities, social insurance, and taxation

ECE 4423.course_description: (Prerequisite: senior or graduate standing, or consent of instructor.) Three hours lecture. Electromagnetic interaction passive sensors, multispectral and hyperspectral optical sensors, active sensors, imaging radar, SAR, Lidar, digital image processing, natural resource applications. (Same as PSS 4483/6483 and ABE 4483/6483)

ABE 4263.course_description: (Prerequisite: ABE 2873 or Consent of Instructor). Two hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Introduction to soil and water management principles; elementary hydrology, erosion control, irrigation, best management practices, and water quality

ABE 8921.course_name: Agricultural and Biological Engineering Seminar II:
ABE 8921.course_description: One hour lecture. Discussion of research needs, review of literature, and development of research work plans

ABE 2173.course_name: Principles of Agricultural and Off-Road Machines:
ABE 2173.course_description: Two hours lecture.  Three hours laboratory.  Operational principles and construction of agricultural and off-road vehicles.  Engine, electrical, and fluid power systems.  Mechanical power transmission, traction performance, and human factors

ME 4624.course_description: (Prerequisites:CHE 3413 or ABE 3813 or ME 3403 or permission of instructors). Three hours lecture. Three hours laboratory . An introduction to research methodologies commonly used in the evaluation of treatments , and mechanical testing. (Same as ABE 4624/6624 and CHE 4624/6624)

PSS 4343.course_description: (Prerequisites: BIO 2113 and PSS 3303; Co-requisite for horticulture majors: PSS 4341). Three hours lecture. Online Course. A detailed review and explanation of principles and practices of controlled environments operation and management

CHE 4624.course_description: (Prerequisites: CHE 3413 or ABE 3813 or ME 3403 or permission of instructors).Three hours lecture.Three hours laboratory. An introduction to research methodologies commonly used in the evaluation of treatments, and mechanical testing.(Same as ABE 4624/6624 and ME 4624/6624)

AEC 3513.course_name: Economics of Food and Fiber Production:
AEC 3513.course_description: (Prerequisite:AEC 3113). Three hours lecture. Economic principles applied to food and fiber production situations with emphasis on firm-level decision analysis

AEC 4343.course_description: (Prerequisites: Senior standing, EC 3123, and AEC 4213 ). Three hours lecture. Techniques and procedures for decision making in farm business as related to determination of optimum enterprise choice and resource combination in both static and dynamic frameworks

ABE 3813.course_description: (Prerequisite: PH 2213). Two hours lecture . Two hours laboratory. Physical properties of biological products and materials. Primary emphasis on measurement and evaluation of dimensional, mechanical, rheological, transport, thermal, electrical, and optical properties

PSS 3133.course_description: (Prerequisites: BIO 2113; CH 1213 or CH 1053). Three hours lecture. Managing weeds; basic weed biology; methods of controlling weeds, introductory herbicide technology, weed control systems, and the fate of herbicides in the environment

ST 8114.course_description: (Prerequisite: MA 1313). Three hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Fall and Spring semesters. Descriptive statistics; sampling distributions; inferences for one and two populations; completely random, block, Latin square, split-plot designs; factorials; simple linear regression; chi-square tests

ECE 4411.course_description: (Prerequisite:Junior Standing). One hour lecture. Lectures by remote sensing experts from industry, academia and governmental agencies on next- generation systems, applications, and economic and societal impact of remote sensing. May be repeated for credit up to four credits. (Same as PSS 4411/6411, FO 4411/6411, GR 4411/6411)

ABE 2873.course_description: (Prerequisite: MA 1323 or equivalent). Two hours lecture . Three hours laboratory. Fundamentals of measurements and traverse computations. Public land surveys. Surveying practice in traverse and topographic surveys

PSS 4483.course_description: (Prerequisite: Senior or graduate standing, or consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. Electromagnetic interactions, passive sensors, multispectral and hyperspectral optical sensors, active sensors, imaging radar, SAR, Lidar, digital image processing, natural resource applications (Same as ECE 4423/6423 and ABE 4483/6483)

ABE 6423.course_name: Measurement and Control in Biological Systems:
ABE 6423.course_description: (Prerequisite: ABE 3413 or graduate standing). Two hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Theory; application of automated measuring and control systems in biological sciences. Includes design/use of transducer interfaces; electronic signal conditioning; data logging; microprocessor based systems

ABE 4163.course_description: (Prerequisites: ABE 2173 or consent of instructor). Two hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Selection, sizing and operation machine systems using cost analysis and systems techniques. Emphasis on agricultural machines used in farming; tillage, planting, harvesting, and conveying agricultural materials

LA 4843.course_description: Three hours lecture. Theory and practices that minimize resource use and pollutant production in the human landscape (same as ABE 4843/6843)

AELC 6613.course_description: Two hours lecture and three hours laboratory. Methods and strategies for teaching middle and high school students skills in agricultural mechanics

AELC 6723.course_description: (Prerequisite: Senior standing or permission of instructor). Two hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Theory and practice in planning objectives and materials, and teaching methods for organizing, delivering, and managing agricultural science programs. Restricted to AELC/AEE teaching concentration students

AELC 6873.course_description: (Prerequisites:  Admission to Teacher Education and senior standing).  Three hours lecture.  Legal, professional, administrative and curricular issues in agricultural and extension education.  Includes philosophy, classroom management, curriculum planning, community involvement and problem solving to plan formal and informal education programs

AELC 8703.course_name: Evaluation of Agricultural and Extension Education Programs:
AELC 8703.course_description: Three hours lecture. Evaluation principles and procedures used in developing and analyzing vocational, technical, and extension education programs

AELC 8203.course_name: Advanced Communications in Agricultural and Extension Education:
AELC 8203.course_description: Three hours lecture. Updating of principles of communicating information in the fields of agriculture/ agribusiness, natural resources, and home economics; review and updating of communications techniques

AELC 8693.course_name: Philosophical Foundations of Agricultural and Extension Education:
AELC 8693.course_description: Three hours lecture. Philosophies, foundational theories, and research on teaching and learning process applied to formal and non-formal programs in agricultural and extension education

AELC 8803.course_name: Applying Research Methods to Agricultural and Extension Education:
AELC 8803.course_description: Three hours lecture. Principles and techniques for planning, conducting, and reporting research; development of effective design of research problems; emphasis on understanding and evaluating scientific reports

EDF 9473.course_name: Qualitative Data Analysis and Presentation in Education:
EDF 9473.course_description: (Prerequisite: EDF 9463). Three hours lecture. Examination, application, and assessment of a range of approaches to analysis and presentation in the design of qualitative research studies in educational settings

AELC 8413.course_name: Methods of Planned Change in Agricultural and Extension Education:
AELC 8413.course_description: Three hours lecture. A study of the theories and processes used by change agents to plan, influence and accomplish change in social, educational and corporate environments

AELC 6103.course_name: Principles and Practices of Extension Education:
AELC 6103.course_description: (Prerequisite: Junior standing).  Three hours lecture. Developing, implementing, and evaluating Extension and non-formal educational programs for youth and adult audiences. Comprehension and application of experiential and transformative learning models and teaching methods

AELC 9103.course_name: Applied Multivariate Data Analysis in AEE:
AELC 9103.course_description: Three hours lecture. Application of multivariate data analysis techniques used in the applied social and life sciences

AELC 8100.course_name: Creative Component Project in Agricultural and Extension Education:
AELC 8100.course_description: Capstone experience supervised by student's major professor and master’s committee.  Individual project involving application of coursework to the student’s career goal.  (Hours and credits to be arranged)

AELC 6403.course_description: Three hours lecture. Needs and interests of youth; developing, managing, and evaluating formal and non-formal youth education programs; volunteer and paraprofessional staff development; securing and developing supportive services

AELC 8503.course_name: Program Planning and Development in Agricultural and Extension Education:
AELC 8503.course_description: Three hours lecture.  Principles, theory, and practice in developing local and state programs of vocational, technical, and extension education

AELC 8833.course_name: Instrumentation and Data Collection Procedures in Social Science Research:
AELC 8833.course_description: Three hours lecture. Selection, development, and analysis of instruments and procedures used for collecting research data in the social and life sciences

AELC 9583.course_name: Analysis and Interpretation of Data in Agricultural and Extension Education Research:
AELC 9583.course_description: (Prerequisite: permission of instructor). Three hours lecture. Principles and techniques for collecting, analyzing, and reporting research in agricultural and extension education. Emphasis on student research project development, student authorship

EDX 8173.course_name: Special Education in the Regular Classroom:
EDX 8173.course_description: Three hours lecture.  Provides a greater understanding of children with disabilities who may be in the regular classroom and suggests methods and techniques for teaching students with disabilities in the regular classroom

AELC 8243.course_name: Administration and Supervision in Agricultural and Extension Education:
AELC 8243.course_description: Three hours lecture. Focus on leadership as a component of good management for educational and human services organizations. Analysis of the decision-making process and discussions about team management, conflict resolution, and situation-based communication skills within the context of a diversity of organizational scenarios

AELC 8603.course_description: (Co-requisite: AELC 8613). Professional full-day public school teaching experience in diverse settings and grade levels for 8 weeks (320 hours) under classroom mentor teachers and university supervisors

AELC 8403.course_name: Directing Learning Experience in Agricultural and Extension Education:
AELC 8403.course_description: Three hours lecture. Planning instructional activities and educational plans for agricultural audiences for formal and non-formal audiences; assessing and evaluating student learning.  Note: Not for students with prior credit in AELC/HDFS 4424 or equivalent

EDF 9463.course_description: (Prerequisite:EDF 9453). Three hours lecture. An in-depth examination of interviewing and observation as two primary qualitative data sources in educational settings

AELC 8613.course_description: (Co-requisite: AELC 8603). Professional full-day public school experience in diverse settings and grade levels for 8 weeks (320 hours) under classroom mentor teachers and university supervisors

AELC 9000.course_name: Research in Agricultural and Extension Education:
AELC 9000.course_description: Hours and credits to be arranged

HDFS 4424.course_name: Teaching Methods in Agricultural and Human Sciences:
HDFS 4424.course_description: (Prerequisite: College of Ag and Life Science major and junior standing). Three hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Planning instruction; selection teaching techniques; developing teaching plans; teaching agricultural/human science topics; using instructional technologies; and evaluating learner progress (Same as AELC/FDM/HDFS 4424/6424)

AELC 8593.course_name: Historical Foundations of Agricultural and Extension Education:
AELC 8593.course_description: Three hours lecture. Historical development of the land-grant system; implications, influences, and evaluation of policies impacting the future of agricultural and extension education

AELC 8853.course_name: Statistics for Social and Life Sciences in Agriculture:
AELC 8853.course_description: Three hours lecture. Introduction to statistical techniques used to analyze quantitative data in the social and life sciences in agriculture

EPY 9213.course_description: (Prerequisites: EPY 6214 and EPY 8214, or equivalent course work). Three hours lecture. An examination of multivariate data analytic techniques for investigating research problems in education

AEC 8621.course_description: Final preparation of the research proposal and presentation of the proposal.  Each semester

AEC 6733.course_description: (Prerequisite:  MA 1613 or MA 1713, EC 3123 and ST 2113 or BQA 2113).  Three hours lecture.  Applications of single-equation estimation techniques to problems in agriculture

AEC 8403.course_description: (Prerequisite:AEC 8163 or EC 8163 or concent of instructor).Three hours lecture. An exploration of how agencies interact stategically. (Same as EC 8403)

AEC 8843.course_description: (Prerequisite:  EC 3123 and ST 2113 or BQA 2113).  Three hours lecture.  An exploration of economists' use of data collection techniques, such as surveys and experiments, with emphasis on analysis of non-market valuation problems

EC 8163.course_description: (Prerequisite: EC 3123 or EC 8103 or equivalent). Three hours lecture. Survey of demand analysis, production, cost, and supply relationships, analysis of pricing under competitive and noncompetitive conditions, analysis of income distribution with emphasis on input pricing

ST 3123.course_description: (Prerequisite: ACT math subscore 24, or grade of C or better in MA 1313 ). Two hours lecture, Two hours laboratory. Basic concepts and methods of statistics, including descriptive statistics, probability random variables, sampling distribution, estimation, hypothesis testing, introduction to analysis of variance, simple linear regression. (Same as MA 3123),

AEC 9000.course_name: Research in Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness:
AEC 9000.course_description: Hours and credits to be arranged

AEC 2713.course_name: Introduction to Food and Resource Economics:
AEC 2713.course_description: Three hours lecture. Each semester. Prerequisite to other Agricultural Economics courses. Economic principles applied to production, value, prices, credit, taxation, land tenure, marketing, international trade, and related problems affecting agriculture

AEC 8233.course_description: (Prerequisite:AEC 8163 or consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. This course is an applied approach to welfare economics,wherein the normative significance of economic events is evaluated, and its application to environmental economics

EC 3333.course_description: (Prerequisites: EC 2113 and EC 2123). Three hours lecture. The application and use of economic models in analyzing and solving selected problems of the firm such as product pricing, product mix, demand forecasting, market analysis

MA 1713.course_description: (Prerequisite: ACT Math subscore 26, or grade of C or better in 1323 or 1453). Three hours lecture. Analytic geometry; functions; limits; continuity; derivatives of algebraic and transcendental functions; applications of the derivative. Honors section available

AEC 8163.course_description: (Prerequisites:  EC 3123; MA 1613 or MA 1713).  Three hours lecture.  Focuses on economic theory related to production, consumption, and markets for products.  Extensions into market structure, welfare economics, and non-market goods will also be discussed

AEC 7000.course_name: Directed Individual Study in Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness:
AEC 7000.course_description: Hours and credits to be arranged

AEC 8611.course_description: (Prerequisite:  EC 3123).  Selection of research topic, development of the research proposal

EC 3113.course_description: (Prerequisites: EC 2113 and EC 2123). Measurement and determination of national income, employment, and output; economic significance of consumption, saving, investment, foreign trade, money and prices, fiscal and monetary policy

AEC 8143.course_description: (Prerequisites: EC 3123 or EC 3333 and AEC 4343/6343). Three hours lecture. Theory of production as related to agricultural production and resource use. Emphasis upon optimal organization of agricultural firms

AEC 3113.course_description: (Prerequisites: AEC 2713 or EC 2123; and MA 1613 or MA 1713). Three hours lecture. Each semester. Introduction to techniques and procedures for the quantitative analysis of economic problems related to the production and distribution of agricultural products

AELC 3203.course_name: Professional Writing in Agriculture, Natural Resources, and Human Sciences:
AELC 3203.course_description: (Prerequisites:  Completion of EN 1103 and 1113 or equivalent and Junior Standing).  Three hours lecture.  Basic principles and techniques in communicating information relevant to agriculture/agribusiness, natural resources, and life sciences

AEC 4223.course_name: Applied Quantitative Analysis in Agricultural Economics:
AEC 4223.course_description: (Prerequisite: AEC 3113; and BQA 2113 or ST 2113 or ST 3123; or consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. Emphasizes the intuitive understanding and practical application of basic quantitative, statistical, econometric, and optimization techniques as they relate to problem solving in agricultural economics

AEC 6713.course_description: (Prerequisites: AEC 3113, EC 3113, and EC 3123). Three hours lecture. Investigation of the basic mathematical methods and techniques currently used to analyze economic problems

AEC 3233.course_name: Introduction to Environmental Economics and Policy:
AEC 3233.course_description: (Prerequisites: AEC 2713 or EC 2123). Examines how economic forces, in concert with other processes, influence environmental quality through private markets and public policy

AEC 4213.course_description: (Prerequisites: AEC 3113 and ACC 2023 or consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. Farm financial structure analysis; capital budgeting and long-term decision making; financial markets for agriculture; farm entry, growth, and transfer

EC 8403.course_description: (Prerequisite: AEC 8163 or EC 8163 or consent of instructor).Three hours lecture. An exploration of how agencies interact strategically. (Same as AEC 8403)

FIN 4123.course_description: (Prerequisite: Junior standing). Three hours lecture. Discussion of the purpose, function mechanics, analysis and application of financial and commodity futures markets in pricing and hedging opportunities (Same as AEC 4123/6123)

MA 1613.course_name: Calculus for Business and Life Sciences I:
MA 1613.course_description: (Prerequisite: ACT Math subscore 24, or grade of C or better in MA 1103 or MA 1313). Three hours lecture. Algebraic and some transcendental functions, solutions of systems of linear equations, limits, continuity, derivatives, applications

ST 2113.course_description: Prerequisite:ACT Math subscore 24(or higher for some sections)or grade of C or better in MA 1103 or MA 1313 or MA 1213. Two hours lecture.Two hours laboratory. Introduction to descriptive statistics, random variables, probability distributions, estimation, confidence intervals, & hypothesis testing. Computer instruction for analysis.(Same as MA 2113)

AEC 8123.course_description: Three hours lecture. Integration of economic theory and econometric methods. Models of consumer demand and agricultural supply under perfect and imperfect competition. Modern estimation techniques, identification strategies, and causal inference

ADS 4124.course_description: (Prerequisite: PO/BIO 3103 and ST/MA/BQA 2113). Three hours lecture and two hours laboratory. The basis for genetic improvement of livestock, including the study of variation, heritable characteristics, mating systems and methods of estimating breeding values

ADS 4223.course_description: (Prerequisite: ADS 1113, ADS 1121 or ADS 1114 and ADS 4114/6114, ADS 4124/6124, and ADS 4613/6613/PHY 6613).  Three hours lecture.  Management and marketing of goats and sheep in production enterprises

CH 1223.course_description: (Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CH 1213). Three hours lecture. The principles of atomic and molecular structure, energetics, dynamics, and synthesis as related to chemical systems

CVM 8973.course_description: (Prerequisite: Graduate standing and consent of instructor) Three hours lecture. The course provides advanced training in research proposal, grant proposal,and manuscript writing. (Same as ADS 8973 and FO 8973)

ADS 4513.course_description: Three hours lecture. Focus on various aspects of companion animal management including breed selection, nutrition, reproduction, and marketing

PHY 8133.course_description: Three hours lecture. Study of factors by which cells communicate: the traditional endocrine system, autocrine, paracrine and neurocrine secretion. Physiological and genetic control of synthesis and secretion

PHY 6112.course_description: One hour lecture. Two hour laboratory. A study of equine reproductive activities and the principles for managing the mare,stallion and foal. (Same as ADS 4112/6112)

ADS 8153.course_description: (Prerequisite: ADS 4114/6114 or equivalent). Three hours lecture. In-depth treatment of rumen function and recent concepts in ruminant nutrition

PHY 6613.course_description: (Prerequisite: BIO 1134 or BIO 1144 and ADS/VS 3014 or equivalent). Three hours lecture. Anatomy and physiology; reproductive cycles; production, evaluation and preservation of gametes; gestation; endocrine regulation; managed reproduction. (Same as ADS 4613/6613)

BCH 6603.course_description: (Prerequisites:  CH 4564, CH 4523/6523 or consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. BCH 4603/6603 must be completed before student may enroll in BCH 4613/6613. Detailed studies of the structure and metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids, enzymes, and coenzymes

FNH 4243.course_name: Composition and Chemical Reactions of Foods:
FNH 4243.course_description: (Prerequisites:  Grade of “C” or better in CH 1213, and CH 2503 or equivalent, and Junior or Senior Standing).  Three hours lecture.  Nature and chemical behavior of food constituents including proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, minerals, water, enzymes and pigments; properties of food systems as related to commercial preparation.  (Same as ADS 4243/6243)

ADS 4114.course_description: (Prerequisites:  CH 2503 and CH 2501 or CH 4513 and CH 4511).  Four hours lecture.  Nutrition of monogastric and ruminant species.  Anatomy, physiology, disgestion, and absorption pertaining to monogastric and ruminants.  Description, functions, sources, deficiency symptoms

ADS 8441.course_name: Journal Club: Evaluation of Current Published Work in Animal and Dairy Sciences:
ADS 8441.course_description: One hour lecture. Publication process, critical evaluation of scientific writing and published works in animal and dairy sciences, assessment of quality and proper presentation of results, and support of conclusions presented

ADS 4813.course_description: (Prerequisites: ADS 1113, ADS 1121 or ADS 1114 and ADS 4114/6114, ADS 4124/6124, and ADS 4613/6613/PHY 6613).  Three hours lecture.  Planning and integrating dairy farm operations; management principles applied to dairy herd operations

VS 3014.course_description: Three hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. A survey of structure and function of animal body systems and a study of their relationships. (Same as ADS 3014)

PHY 6623.course_description: (Prerequisite: BIO 1134 or BIO 1144 and ADS/VS 3014 or equivalent). Two hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Anatomy, physiology, and pathology of the mammary gland; nervous and hormonal control of lactation, theories of milk secretion, modern methods of milking, factors affecting lactation.  (Same as ADS 4623/6623)

ADS 4113.course_description: Three hours lecture. (Prerequisites: ADS 1113, ADS 1121 or ADS 1114 and ADS 4114/6114, ADS 4124/6124, and ADS 4613/6613/PHY 6613). Feeding, management, breeding, production, and marketing of swine

FO 8973.course_description: (Prerequisite: Graduate standing and consent of instructor) Three hours lecture. The course provides advanced training in research proposal, grant proposal,and manuscript writing. (Same as ADS 8973 and CVM 8973)

ADS 3013.course_description: (Prerequisites: BIO 1134 or BIO 1144). Three hours lecture. A survey of structure and function of animal body systems and a study of their relationships

ADS 8243.course_description: (Prerequisite: ADS 4613/6613 or its equivalent). Three hours lecture. An advanced study of the reproductive process with emphasis on reproductive endocrinology and the physiology of fertility. (Same as PHY 8243.)

FNH 8423.course_description: Three hours lecture. Basic study of the value of meat and how this information is applied to the evaluation, processing, and preservation of meat, meat products, and meat by-products. (Same as ADS 8423)

ADS 1113.course_description: Three hours lecture.  Fundamental principles of livestock, dairy, and poultry science.  (ADS majors must earn a C or better to graduate)

CH 1213.course_description: (Prerequisities:ACT Math subscore 24 or  grade of C or better in MA 1313) Three hours lecture.The principles of atomic and molecular structure, energetics, dynamics, and synthesis as related to chemical systems

CH 2503.course_description: (Prerequisite: CH 1213 or CH 1043). Three hours lecture. A terminal course in organic chemistry. Common aliphatic, aromatic, and heterocyclic compounds

CH 2501.course_description: (Prerequisite: CH 1211 or CH 1051). Three hours laboratory. A laboratory course to accompany CH 2503

ADS 4723.course_description: (ADS 4723 Prerequisite: Junior/Senior undergraduate and pre or co-requisite of BIO 3304 General Microbiology; ADS 6723: No prerequisite). Three hours lecture. This course introduces the microbial ecosystems in animals and how they interact with hosts to influence animal metabolism, immunity, and behavior

ADS 4233.course_description: (Prerequisites: ADS 1113 and ADS 1121 or ADS 1114 and ADS 4114/6114, ADS 4124/6124 and ADS 4613/6613/PHY 6613).  Three hours lecture.  Breeding, feeding, management, and training of the horse

BIO 3103.course_description: Two hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. (Prerequisites: MA 1313 or higher, BIO 1134 or higher or BIO 2113 or higher ). Principles of heredity, genetic material, and gene expressions. (Same as GNS 3103, PO 3103)

ADS 6723.course_description: (ADS 4723 Prerequisite: Junior/Senior undergraduate and pre or co-requisite of BIO 3304 General Microbiology; ADS 6723: No prerequisite). Three hours lecture. This course introduces the microbial ecosystems in animals and how they interact with hosts to influence animal metabolism, immunity, and behavior

ADS 8111.course_description: Survey of current literature; preparation, organization, and presentation of papers on selected topics in animal and dairy sciences. (Course is repeatable and may be taken 6 times)

ADS 6553.course_name: Current Literature in Animal and Dairy Sciences:
ADS 6553.course_description: (Prerequisite: Junior, Senior or graduate standing). Three hours lecture. Evaluation of current research in animal and dairy sciences and its application to production and management

ADS 6633.course_name: Immunology and Disease in Domestic Animals:
ADS 6633.course_description: (Prerequisite: ADS 3013). Three hours lecture. This course will cover common diseases in domestic animals. Curriculum will include immunology, disease transfer, prevention methods, detection techniques, treatment options, and potential impacts on the animal, producer, and industry

BCH 4013.course_description: (Prerequisite: CH 2503, BIO 1134 or equivalent.) Three hours lecture. A survey of biochemistry designed to provide the non-major with a comprehensive background in the field. (Credit will not be given to students matriculating in the Biochemistry or Molecular Biology degree programs.)

PHY 6611.course_description: (Prerequisite or Co-requisite: ADS 4613/6613/PHY 6613). Three hours laboratory. Artificial insemination and rectal palpation of reproductive organs of cattle; semen collection, evaluation, processing and handling. (Same as ADS 4611/6611)

BIO 1134.course_description: Three hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Principles of Biology including nature of science, chemistry of life, cell structure and division, cellular respiration, photosynthesis, Mendelian, chromosomal and molecular genetics, evolution, and ecology

CH 4511.course_description: (Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CH 1221 and CH 1223 or in CH 1244. Prior credit or concurrent enrollment in CH 4513). Three hours laboratory. A laboratory course to accompany CH 4513/6513

BIO 3304.course_description: (Prerequisites: CH 1053 or CH 1223). Two hours lecture. Four hours laboratory. For science majors. Students may not have credit for both BIO 1043 and BIO 3304. Fundamentals; techniques in staining and culture of microorganisms

ADS 8162.course_description: (Prerequisite: ADS 4114/6114 or equivalent). Two hours lecture. Monogastric nutritional relationships with special emphasis on swine nutrition. Metabolic functions, dietary requirements, deficiency symptoms and distribution of nutrients in feedstuffs

ADS 9000.course_name: Research in Animal and Dairy Science:
ADS 9000.course_description: Hours and credits to be arranged

ADS 4613.course_description: (Prerequisite: BIO 1134 or BIO 1144 and ADS 3013 or equivalent). Three hours lecture. Anatomy and physiology; reproductive cycles; production, evaluation and preservation of gametes; gestation; endocrine regulation; managed reproduction. (Same as PHY 6613)

BCH 4603.course_description: (Prerequisites:  CH 4564, CH 4523/6523 or consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. BCH 4603/6603 must be completed before student may enroll in BCH 4613/6613. Detailed studies of the structure and metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids, enzymes, and coenzymes

CH 4513.course_description: (Prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CH 1223 or in CH 1244). Three hours lecture. A systematic study of organic chemistry including aliphatic, aromatic, and heterocyclic compounds

ADS 8333.course_description: Three hours lecture.  The biochemical aspects of post-absorptive nutrient utilization, intermediary metabolism, and tissue-level accretion in livestock species will be discussed.  Particular emphasis will be placed on the   contribution of nutrients to the metabolic disposition of economically important tissues including muscle and adipose

ADS 4321.course_description: (Prerequisite or Co-requisite: ADS 4323/6323).  Two hours laboratory.  Management practices for beef cattle operations

BIO 1144.course_description: Three hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Form and function of organisms including body plans and phylogeny,human evolution, plant anatomy and physiology, animal anatomy and  physiology,reproduction, development, and animal behavior

ST 8214.course_description: (Prerequisite: ST 8114) Three hours lecture. Three hours laboratory. Offered spring semester. Procedures in planning and analyzing experiments; simple, multiple, and curvilinear regression; factorial arrangement of treatments; confounding; fractional replication; block designs; lattices; split-plots

FNH 4313.course_description:
(Prerequisite: Junior standing or greater, ADS/FNH 3314, CH 1223 and/or Instructor Consent). Three hours lecture. Exploration of the ultra-structure of muscle, (pre- and post-harvest), and the microbiology, inspection and safety, nutritional properties, and sensory characteristics of muscle foods. 
(Same as ADS 4313/6313.)

BCH 6013.course_description: (Prerequisite: CH 2503, BIO 1134 or equivalent.) Three hours lecture. A survey of biochemistry designed to provide the non-major with a comprehensive background in the field. (Credit will not be given to students matriculating in the Biochemistry or Molecular Biology degree programs.)

ADS 8133.course_description: (Prerequisite: BCH 4013/6013 or BCH 4603/6603 or ADS 8333 or equivalent). Three hours lecture. Study of factors by which cells communicate: the traditional endocrine system, autocrine, paracrine and neurocrine secretion. Physiological and genetic control of synthesis and secretion. (Same as PHY 8133)

ADS 8533.course_description: (Prerequisite:  ADS 4323/6323 or consent of instructor).  Three hours lecture.  Systems management approaches to profitable and sustainable beef cattle production including cow-calf, stocker, and feedlot industry segments

ADS 4323.course_description: (Prerequisites:  ADS 1113, ADS 1121 or ADS 1114 and ADS 4114/6114, ADS 4124/6124, and ADS 4613/6613/PHY 6613).  Three hours lecture.  Breeding, feeding, management, and marketing of beef cattle

ADS 6523.course_description: (Prerequisite:  Junior, senior or graduate standing).  Three hours lecture.  Use of the internet in making management decisions in livestock industries, with emphasis on use in livestock production enterprises

BCH 6613.course_description: (Prerequisites: CH 4564, CH 4523/6523 or consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. BCH 4603/6603 must be completed before student may enroll in BCH 4613/6613. Detailed studies of the structure and metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids, enzymes, and coenzymes

ADS 1121.course_description: (Prerequisite:  Prior credit or concurrent enrollment in ADS 1113).  Two hours laboratory.  Practical application of essential knowledge and skills needed in the livestock, dairy and poultry science

ADS 4243.course_name: Composition and Chemical Reactions of Foods:
ADS 4243.course_description: (Prerequisites:  Grade of “C” or better in CH 1213, and CH 2503 or equivalent, and Junior or Senior Standing).  Three hours lecture.  Nature and chemical behavior of food constituents including proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, minerals, water, enzymes and pigments; properties of food systems as related to commercial preparation.  (Same as FNH 4243/6243)

FNH 4013.course_description: (Prerequisites:  Grade of “C” or better in FNH 2293 and KI 2603 and Junior Standing).  Two hours lecture.  Two hours laboratory.  Selection, utilization, interpretation, and evaluation of anthropometric, laboratory, clinical and dietary methods available for the assessment of nutritional status

PO 6844.course_description: Three hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Anatomy and physiology of the fowl with emphasis on morphology, structure, and function of the avian body. (Same as PHY 6844)

BIO 4114.course_description: (Prerequisites: Seven hours of biological science and two semesters of organic chemistry). Three hours lecture. Three hours laboratory. A study of the morphology and function of the cell. (Same as PHY 4114/6114)

ADS 4623.course_description: (Prerequisite: BIO 1134 or BIO 1144 and ADS/VS 3014 or equivalent). Two hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Anatomy, physiology, and pathology of the mammary gland; nervous and hormonal control of lactation, theories of milk secretion, modern methods of milking, factors affecting lactation. (Same as PHY 6623)

ADS 4112.course_description: One hour lecture. Two hours laboratory. A study of equine reproductive activities and the principles for managing the mare,stallion and foal. (Same as PHY 6112)

EPP 4154.course_description: Two hours lecture. Four hours laboratory. General Entomology is designed to introduce the biology and diversity of insects. Lectures cover most of basic biological phenomena of insects including morphology, physiology, development, ecology, and interactions with human activities. Lab activities include insect collection, classification, and hands-on experiments

ADS 4611.course_description: (Prerequisite or Co-Requisite: ADS 4613/6613/PHY 6613). Three hours laboratory. Artificial insemination and rectal palpation of reproductive organs of cattle; semen collection, evaluation, processing and handling. (Same as PHY 6611)

EPP 8333.course_description: (Prerequisite: EPP 4543. Three hours lecture. Fall semester. Physiological and biochemical actions of pesticides and therapeutic drugs. Pesticide metabolism and resistance. Insecticide synergism. Natural toxins and venoms. (Same as PHY 8333)

BIO 4514.course_description: (Prerequisites: Ten hours of biological science and organic chemistry). Three hours lecture. Three hours laboratory. Functions and interrelationship of the systems of the body. (Same as PHY 4514/6514)

EPP 4543.course_description: (Prerequisite: Principles of Biochemistry (BCH 4013), or General Biochemistry I (BCH 4603), or permission from instructor). Three hours lecture. Principles of toxicology, history of insecticide use, mode of action for of major insecticide classes, metabolism of insecticides, development of pest resistance, and environmental fate of insecticides

SO 4633.course_description: Three hours lecture. Examination of relationship between language and society. How language varies regionally and socially; people’s use of and attitudes toward different ways of speaking. (Same as AN 4633/6633 and EN 4633/6633)

AN 8533.course_description: Three hours lecture. Archaeological theory and its implications for practice, focusing on evolutionary archaeology but also including culture history, processual, reconstructionist, and post-processual approaches

AN 1143.course_description: Three hours lecture. Introduction to the study of social, political, and economic organization, magic and religion, personality, and art

EN 4403.course_description: Three hours lecture. The descriptive and historical study of language; linguistic analysis and comparisons; language classification; language in its social and cultural setting. (Same as AN 4403/6403)

SO 4173.course_description: (Prerequisite: AN 1103 or SO 1003 or consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. A study of the interaction between human society and the environment including the social aspects of environmental problems. (Same as AN 4173/6173)

AN 4313.course_description: Two hours lecture and two hours laboratory. Identification of each human bone both complete and fragmentary. Study of skeletal and dental development, sex differences, age changes, hard tissue histology, trauma analysis, and paleopathology. Guest lectures in advanced laboratory methods

AN 8011.course_description: One hour seminar. Students are introduced to norms of professional behavior in Applied Anthropology, with focus on success in graduate school and preparation for the job market

AN 6523.course_description: (Prerequisite: AN 1543 or consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. Survey of cultural resource management practices, Federal and State historic preservation laws, research proposal design, significance assessments, professional ethics, employee/client relationships, and public education

EN 4623.course_description: Three hours lecture. Examination of language as a part of culture, a source of knowledge about other aspects of culture, and a social behavior. (Same as AN 4623/6623 and SO 4623/6623)

SO 4623.course_description: Three hours lecture. Examination of language as a part of culture, a source of knowledge about other aspects of culture, and a social behavior. (Same as AN 4623/6623 and EN 4623/6623)

SO 1003.course_description: Three hours lecture. The nature and development of culture; social aspects of personality; analysis of community life, population trends, social classes, institutions, processes, and organization; culture change

GR 8183.course_description: Three hours lecture. This course investigates the relationship between culture, space, and place, introducing key ways social scientists approach these concerns. A central focus is the relationship between modes of social difference—particularly race, gender, and class—and cultural meaning in spatial power relations. (Same as AN 8183)

AN 8013.course_description: Students are introduced to quantitative methods utilized in anthropological research. Students will examine anthropological research design, sampling strategies, probability theory, and various statistical approaches

AN 6123.course_description: (Prerequisite: AN 1103 or its equivalent or consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. A history of the development of anthropological theory; an analysis of contemporary theoretical formulations and approaches

EM 6123.course_name: An Introduction to the Finite Element Method:
EM 6123.course_description: (Prerequisite: Consent of Instructor). Three hours lecture. Introduction to the mathematical theory, formulation, and computer implementation of the finite element method. App- lication to one-and two-dimensional problems in engineering mechanics

AN 3343.course_description: Three hours lecture.  Examination of the foundations and role of forensic anthropology in the forensic sciences.  Review of the biological profile, assessment of bone trauma, identification of taphonomic agents, and an exploration of mass disasters and human rights violations

EN 4633.course_description: Three hours lecture. Examination of relationship between language and society. How language varies regionally and socially; people’s use of and attitudes toward different ways of speaking. (Same as AN 4633/6633 and SO 4633/6633)

AN 4543.course_description: (Prerequisite: Completion of any 1000-level history course). Three hours lecture. A study of the origins and development of civilizations in Mesopotamia, Egypt, and Syria-Palestine from prehistoric times to the end of the Persian period (Same as MEC/REL/HI 4403/6403)

AN 1103.course_description: Three hours lecture.  What does it mean to be human? Exploration of human nature, variation, and culture; relationships between human bodies and human culture; and human relationships to other species, living and dead, across time and space. Introduction to biological, cultural, linguistic, and archaeological perspectives on humans

HI 4403.course_description: (Prerequisite: Completion of any 1000-level history course). Three hours lecture. A study of the origins and development of civilizations in Mesopotamia, Egypt, and Syria-Palestine from prehistoric times to the end of the Persian period. (Same as MEC 4403/6403 and REL 4403/6403)

AN 1344.course_name: Biological Anthropology: The Making of Us:
AN 1344.course_description: Three hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Biology of evolution, mechanism of speciation, concepts of race, and the primate order are explored culminating in an appreciation of paleoanthropology, human evolution, and human variation

AN 1543.course_description: Three hours lecture. A survey of early cultural development throughout the world; emphasis on archaeological techniques, interpretations and theories of development

PH 8743.course_description: (Prerequisites: PH 4723 and MA 3313). Schrodinger theory, spherically symmetric systems, matrix mechanics, angular momentum and spin, time-independent perturbation theory

PH 8313.course_description: (Prerequisite: PH 4333 or equivalent). Maxwell's theory of electromagnetism. Boundary value problems in electrostatics, static multipole moments, theory of dielectrics, magnetostatics, plane electromagnetic waves, simple radiating systems. (Same as ECE 8313)

PH 9000.course_description: Hours and credits to be arranged

PH 8213.course_description: (Prerequisite: A good undergraduate training in physics and mathematics consent of instructor). Coordinate systems and transformations, tensors, and matrices. Particle dynamics, variational principles, Lagrange's and Hamilton's equations, rigid body motion, special relativity in mechanics

PH 8243.course_description: (Prerequisite: PH 8233). Topics will vary but may include analytic functions, Fourier analysis, Green's functions, integral transforms, partial differential equations and integral equations

PH 8233.course_description: (Prerequisite: Consent of instructor). Topics will vary, but may include linear vector spaces, tensor analysis, group theory, function space and orthogonal polynomials

PH 8753.course_description: (Prerequisite: PH 8743). Time dependent perturbation theory, identical particles, theory of scattering, quantum-statistical mechanics, introduction of relativistic quantum mechanics, quantum electrodynamics

BCH 6804.course_description: (Prerequisite:Coregistration in BCH 4613/6613). Two hours lecture. Four hours laboratory. A comprehensive course to teach the student the modern methods of molecular biology. (Same as GNS 4804/6804),

BCH 7000.course_name: Directed Individual Study in Biochemistry, Molecular Biology, Entomology and Plant Pathology:
BCH 7000.course_description: Hours and credits to be arranged

BCH 8101.course_description: Review of current literature; individual presentation of research or classical topics. Course can be taken twice for credit

BCH 6414.course_description: (Prerequisite: Coregistration in BCH 4603/6603). Two hours lecture. Four hours laboratory. A comprehensive course to teach the student the modern methods of protein biochemistry

EPP 8673.course_description: (Prerequisite: Graduate standing or permission of instructor). Three hours lecture. Comprehensive overview of molecular interactions between microbes and their hosts and vectors leading to disease, colonization, symbiosis, vector transmission, immune responses, and other outcomes. Mammalian, plant, and insect systems will be covered. (Same as BCH 8673)

PSS 8653.course_description: (Prerequisites:BCH 4113/6113 or BCH 4713/6713 or BCH 8643 or consent of instructor) Overview of genome structure and evolution with emphasis on genomics, the use of molecular biology, robotics, and advanced computational methods to efficiently study genomes. (Same as BCH 8653)

EPP 4113.course_description: (Prerequisites: BIO 1134 and Bio 1144 or consent of instructor). Two hours lecture. Three hours laboratory. Acquiring a general knowledge of the principles of plant pathology through a study of selected plant diseases of economic importance for Mississippi

BCH 8643.course_description: (Prerequisites: PO 3103, or BIO 3103, and Coregistration in BCH 5613/7613). Three hours lecture. Study of the gene and its expression with emphasis on structure and function in higher organisms. (Same as GNS 8643)

EPP 7000.course_name: Directed Individual Study in Entomology and Plant Pathology:
EPP 7000.course_description: Hours and credits to be arranged

EPP 4254.course_description: (Prerequisite:  BIO 1134 or consent of instructor).  Two hours lecture.  Four hours laboratory.  Subjects include fungal structures, function and physiology, reproduction, genetics, emphasis in taxonomy and influence of reproductive stages of Ascomycetes, Basidiomycetes on plant and forest ecosystems

BCH 4613.course_description: (Prerequisites: CH 4564, CH 4523/6523 or consent of instructor). Three hours lecture. BCH 4603/6603 must be completed before student may enroll in BCH 4613/6613. Detailed studies of the structure and metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids, enzymes, and coenzymes

CH 4564.course_description: (Prerequisite: Grade of C or better in CH 4511 and CH 4513 or in CH 4554). Three hours lecture. Three hours laboratory. Integrated lecture-lab course for chemistry majors. A systematic study of organic chemistry including aliphatic, aromatic, and heterocyclic compounds

EPP 2213.course_description: Two hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. Introduction to structure, function, ecology, taxonomy and evolution of the largest and most diverse group of organisms and how they impact humans and their environment

FNH 8173.course_description: (Prerequisites: EPP 4254/6254 or consent of instructor). One hour lecture and four hours laboratory. This course prepares students to identify fungal causal agents associated with agricultural problems, including food science, agronomy, veterinary science, horticulture, forestry, and plant pathology. (Same as EPP 8173)

PHY 8333.course_description: (Prerequisite: EPP 4543/6543 or elementary biochemistry). (Same as EPP 8333)

EPP 4164.course_description: (Prerequisite: EPP 4154). Two hours lecture. Six hours laboratory. Spring semester. Advanced study of insect classification

BCH 8633.course_description: (Prerequisites: BCH 4613/6613). Three hours lecture. A study of enzymes; their purification, classification, kinetics and mechanisms

PO 3103.course_description: Two hours lecture. Two hours laboratory. (Prerequisites: MA 1313 or higher, BIO 1134 or higher or BIO 2113 or higher ). Principles of heredity, genetic material, and gene expressions. (Same as BIO 3103, GNS 3103)

CH 4523.course_description: (Prerequisite: Grade of C or better in CH 4513/6513 or in CH 4554). Three hours lecture. A systematic study of organic chemistry including aliphatic, aromatic, and heterocyclic compounds

BCH 8653.course_description: (Prerequisites:BCH 4113/6113 or BCH 4713/6713 or BCH 8643 or consent of instructor). Overview of genome structure and evolution with emphasis on genomics, the use of molecular biology, robotics, and advanced computational methods to efficiently study genomes. (Same as PSS 8653)

BCH 6713.course_description: (Prerequisite for BCH 4713: Co-registration in BCH 4613). Three hours lecture. A study of basic molecular processes such as DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Offered fall semester

ME 8144.course_description: (Prerequisite:Consent of Instructor). One hour lecture. Six hours laboratory. Introduction to TEM including life sciences (tissue) and engineering (crystalline materials) topics. (Same as EPP 8144)

BCH 8654.course_description: (Prerequisite: BCH 4613/6613). Four hours lecture. An advanced in-depth study of anabolic and catabolic pathways involved in cellular metabolism. Bioenergetics and control mechanisms will be emphasized

FNH 4253.course_description: (Prerequisites:  FNH Majors:  Grade of “C” or better or concurrent enrollment in BCH 4013 and Junior or Senior Standing; or BCH Major).  Three hours face to face lecture or web-based distance instruction.  In-depth study of the chemistry and functionality of macronutrients in food systems and their biochemical impact on the human body.  (Same as BCH 4253/6253)

EPP 8111.course_description: Consideration of recent advances and problems in Entomology and Plant Pathology; student participation, general discussion

PSS 8631.course_description: (Prerequisites:PSS/BCH 8653 BCH 4713/6713 or BCH 8643 or consent of instructor). Review and discussion of classic and current genomics literature;individual presentation of a seminar highlighting an area of genomics research. (Same as BCH 8631)

BIO 4113.course_description: (Prerequisites: MA 1313 or equivalent, BIO 1134 and BIO 1144, BIO 3103 or BIO 4133). Historical development of evolutionary theory; phylogeny and systematic; historic or organic evolution; molecular and phenotypic variation in populations; genetic drift and natural selection; speciation

BCH 4113.course_description: Three hours lecture. A survey of molecular biology and genetics designed to provide the non-major with a comprehensive background in the field. (Credit will not be given to students matriculating in the Biochemistry or Molecular Biology degree program)

BCH 8673.course_description: (Prerequisite: Graduate standing or permission of instructor). Three hours lecture. Comprehensive overview of molecular interactions between microbes and their hosts and vectors leading to disease, colonization, symbiosis, vector transmission, immune responses, and other outcomes. Mammalian, plant, and insect systems will be covered. (Same as EPP 8673)
